name: obsolete-afsc-race-eco-foci-chlorophyll-groundtruth-data-for-chlorophyll-fluorescence-sensors-
notes: These data are part of a ocean observation study by Stabeno, Napp, and Whitledge sponsored, in part, but the North Pacific Research Board  (Project 410; http://doc.nprb.org).  The grant was titled

Moorings were maintained on the southeastern Bering Sea shelf at M2n(56.9B0N, 164.1B0W), and at M4 (57.9B0N, 168.9B0W). Shipboardnmeasurements of temperature, salinity, nutrients, chlorophyll, fluorescence andnzooplankton were collected around the moorings on two cruises (3MF04 - April 2004 and 8MF04 - September 2004) to ground truth in situ sensors on the moorings. This long-term monitoring supported major findings: (1) The timing of the spring phytoplankton bloom is determined by the presence of ice, with an early bloom occurring if ice is present after mid-March and later bloom occurring if therenis no sea-ice after mid-March; (2) During the last decade, the southeastern Bering Seanshelf has undergone a marked warming (~3B0C) that is closely associated with a markedndecrease of sea ice over the southeastern shelf; (3) Nutrients supply and summer salinitynover the shelf has not significantly changed during the last three decades; (4) There is annindication that cold water zooplankton species (e.g Calanus marshallae) are occurringnin reduced abundance in association with the warming. While the warming over thensoutheastern shelf is primarily related to the reduction of ice extent, a combination ofnother mechanisms are important: the presence over the eastern shelf of a relatively mildnair mass during winter since 2000; a shorter ice season caused by a later fall transitionnand/or earlier spring transition; increased flow through Unimak Pass during winternintroducing warm Gulf of Alaska water onto the shelf; and a thermal feedbacknmechanism whereby warmer, summer ocean temperatures delay the southward advectionnof sea ice during winter.
